title: 107_hr1975
content: Modified timetable for initial compliance with administrative simplification standards for health care information. The Social Security Act is amended to require compliance with initial standards or specifications within 24 months after the Secretary determines final regulations containing all required standards have been promulgated. The Social Security Act requires compliance with standards within 24 months after final regulations are implemented, including unique health identifiers for individuals, health plans, and providers. The Social Security Act mandates compliance with regulations within 24 months, including unique health identifiers for individuals, health plans, and providers. Regulations must be promulgated in accordance with section 553 of title 5, United States Code, without requiring consideration of subsequent modifications made under section 1174(b). The Social Security Act requires compliance with regulations within 24 months, including unique health identifiers for individuals, health plans, and providers. A conforming amendment specifies that the Secretary will determine small health plans. The effective date for these amendments is retroactive to the enactment of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996. The text chunk "SEC. 2. NO EFFECT ON REGULATIONS GOVERNING PRIVACY OF INDIVIDUALLY IDENTIFIABLE HEALTH INFORMATION." is a statement indicating that certain regulations governing the privacy of individually identifiable health information will not be affected. The amendments made by section 1 and section 1175(b) of the Social Security Act will not affect the compliance dates for implementing privacy standards for individually identifiable health information. This includes provisions in subpart E of part 164 of the Code of Federal Regulations and other related provisions. The text discusses provisions in part 160 of title 45, Code of Federal Regulations, and the authority of the Secretary of Health and Human Services under section 264 of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996. SEC. 3. STUDY ON EFFECT OF ADMINISTRATIVE SIMPLIFICATION REQUIREMENTS. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to examine the impact of part C of title XI of the Social Security Act on health plans, providers, clearinghouses, and the Department of Health and Human Services. The study will also assess compliance progress. The deadline for submitting a report on the study is October 31, 2003. The terms "plan", "health care provider", and "health care clearinghouse" are defined in section 1171 of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1320d).
